column1: Delaware City is close to the Delaware City Oil Refinery belonging to PBF Energy.
Delaware Route 9 serves as the main road through Delaware City
column2: passing southeast-northwest through the city on 5th Street. South of Delaware City
column3: DE 9 passes over the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal on the Reedy Point Bridge. North of Delaware City
column4: DE 9 has an intersection with Delaware Route 72
column5: which provides access to U.S. Route 13 and Delaware Route 1. DART First State provides bus service to Delaware City along Route 25
column6: which heads north to Wilmington along US 13. Delaware City is at the east end of the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal
column7: which provides boaters with access to the Delaware River to the east and the Chesapeake Bay to the west. The Forts Ferry Crossing is a passenger ferry that provides access from Delaware City to Fort Delaware on Pea Patch Island in the Delaware River and to Fort Mott in New Jersey.

column3: provides electricity and natural gas to Delaware City. The water system in Delaware City is owned by the city and operated under contract by Artesian Water Company
column4: a subsidiary of Artesian Resources. Sewer service in Delaware City is provided by New Castle County. Trash collection is provided under contract by Waste Industries while recycling collection is provided by the city. Cable and internet in Delaware City is provided by Atlantic Broadband and Verizon. Telephone service is provided mostly by Verizon
column5: with Cavalier Telephone also serving the city.

column1: Delaware City's Fort DuPont State Park contains the home field of the Diamond State Base Ball Club
column2: a vintage base ball team.  The Diamond State Base Ball Club typically plays 4-6 games there per year.  The Diamond State Base Ball Club also plays at least once per year at Fort Delaware on Pea Patch Island and also at nearby Port Penn
column3: Delaware.  The Diamond State Base Ball Club is a non-profit amateur organization created for the purposes of providing physical fitness to its members
column4: educating the public on the history of baseball and local history
column5: and serving as a point of public pride.
